p.s: In the given extract from Act II scene 2 from William Shakespeare's Romeo and Juliet from 1597 the author makes use of several stylistic devices and a specific choice of language.

At first, Juliet does not seem as in love as Romeo does, but more worried and fearing someone of her family will find out she has kissed a Montague who is now sneaking into her families'family's garden at night.
During the scene she develops less fear which is finally overwhelmed by her feelings for Romeo and she starts to be mad about him too and shares her loving feelings.
In line 58 one can find a metaphorametaphor as Juliet states My ears have not yet drunk a hundred words.
It explains how Juliet has not even heard Romeo's voice a lot, but still recognized it as he comes out of hiding in her garden right before the beginning of the extract.
The use of this metaphorametaphor makes the description of their new, fresh relationship more powerful for the reader.
In line 64 if any of my kinsmen find thee here and line 78 if they do see thee, ... the author makes use of a repetionrepetition.
Juliet points out the danger of the situation, as her relatives would kill Romeo if they saw him in the Capulet's garden.
This repitionrepetition of the phrase enriches the meaning and emotional appeal as it is very dangerous for Romeo to stay there.
In line 66 with love's light wings Shakespeare uses another metaphorametaphor.
Romeo states how it was easy for him to climb the wall to get into the Capulet's garden.
Although this wall is really high, as Juliet says, he was so motivated by love to see Juliet that it was easy for him to climb that wall.
The use of this specific metaphorametaphor creates an image in the reader's mind of Romeo flying over the wall with wings spreading over him.

In line 75 I have night's cloak to hide me Romeo tries to calm Juliet down who is worried he will be seen, by referingreferring to the darkness of the night, which makes it easy for Romeo to hide from Juliet's relatives.
This metaphorametaphor lets the reader weel emphasized by the thought of safety and creates another image.

Last but not least in line 85 one can find another metaphorametaphor mask of the night is on my face in which Juliet is thankful and charmed by Romeo's words and assures him she is blushing, which he cannot see as it is dark at night.
Again, the image of Romeo and Juliet in the Capulet's garden at night is created.
This Stylistic Devicestylistic device could also be interpreted as a repitionrepetition, as in line 75 Shakespeare already focused on the darkness of the night.
To sum up, one can say that Shakespeare obviously has a very unique style of writing.
The creation of new words and grammar is typical for the Elizabethan time, Shakespeare lived in.

I personally recognized a big number of metaphorasmetaphors throughout the scene which is nice for the reader, because he can create a lot of images in his mind which makes reading this cene more entertaining.
